{{good article}}{{Infobox album | Name = ...Baby One More Time | Type = studio | Artist = [[Britney Spears]] | Cover = ... Baby One More Time.png | Border = yes | Released = {{start date|1999|1|12}} | Recorded = August 1997 – June 1998 | Genre = {{Flat list| *[[Pop music|Pop]] *[[dance-pop]] *[[teen pop]] }} | Length = {{duration|m=42|s=20}} | Label = [[Jive Records|Jive]] | Producer = {{Flat list| *[[All Seeing I|The All Seeing I]] *[[Jörgen Elofsson]] *[[David Kreuger]] *[[Kristian Lundin]] *[[Per Magnusson]] *[[Max Martin]] *[[Rami Yacoub|Rami]] *Eric Foster White }} | This album = {{ubl|'''''...Baby One More Time'''''|(1999)}} | Next album = {{ubl|''[[Oops!... I Did It Again (album)|Oops!... I Did It Again]]''|(2000)}} | Misc = {{Extra album cover | Upper caption = International cover | Type = studio | Cover = ... Baby One More Time (International).png | Border = yes }} {{Singles | Name = ...Baby One More Time | Type = studio | single 1 = [[...Baby One More Time]] | single 1 date = {{start date|1998|9|30}} | single 2 = [[Sometimes (Britney Spears song)|Sometimes]] | single 2 date = {{start date|1999|4|30}} | single 3 = [[(You Drive Me) Crazy]] | single 3 date = {{start date|1999|8|23}} | single 4 = [[Born to Make You Happy]] | single 4 date = {{start date|1999|12|6}} | single 5 = [[From the Bottom of My Broken Heart]] | single 5 date = {{start date|1999|12|15}} }}}} '''''...Baby One More Time''''' is the debut [[studio album]] by American recording artist [[Britney Spears]]. It was released on January 12, 1999, by [[Jive Records]]. In June 1997, while Spears negotiated with manager [[Lou Pearlman]] to join female pop group [[Innosense]], her mother asked family friend and entertainment lawyer [[Larry Rudolph]] for his opinion and submitted a tape of Spears singing over a [[Whitney Houston]] [[karaoke]] song. Rudolph decided to pitch her to record labels, sending them a demo tape with an unused song from [[Toni Braxton]]. Jive was interested and appointed the singer to work with producer Eric Foster White. After hearing the recorded material, Jive signed Spears to a multi-album deal. Spears traveled to Sweden to work with producers [[Max Martin]], [[Denniz Pop]] and [[Rami Yacoub]], among others. Martin showed Spears and her management a track titled "Hit Me Baby One More Time", which was originally written for American R&B group [[TLC (band)|TLC]]; however, they rejected the track. Spears later claimed that she felt excited when she heard it and knew it was going to be a hit record. By June 1998, the album had been finished. Critics gave the album mixed reviews, describing the singer as a [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] next door, considering it silly and premature. The album was successful on the charts, reaching the top five in several countries, while reaching number one in Canada and the United States. It also received several certifications around the world, including a [[RIAA certification|fourteen-times platinum]] certification by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA), for shipments of over 14 million units in the country. ''...Baby One More Time'' is Spears' most successful album, selling over 30 million copies worldwide, making it one of the [[List of best-selling albums|best-selling albums of all time]] and the best-selling album by a teenage solo artist. Five singles came from the album. "[[...Baby One More Time]]" became a worldwide success and one of the [[List of best-selling singles worldwide|best-selling singles of all time]], at over ten million copies. The album was promoted with appearances on live television, and also by the [[...Baby One More Time Tour]] in 1999, with a second leg titled [[...Baby One More Time Tour|Crazy 2k Tour]] in 2000. Spears claimed she wasn't able to explore her vocal ability on the album. This album set Spears' international [[Pop icon|pop culture icon]] image and launched her career. The album earned Spears [[Grammy]] nominations for [[Best New Artist]] and [[Best Female Pop Vocal Performance]] for "...Baby One More Time." ==Background and development== {{Quote box|width=30%|align=left|quote="I had been in studio for about six months listening and recording material, but I hadn't really heard a hit yet. When I started working with Max Martin in Sweden, he played the demo for 'Baby One More Time' for me, and I knew from the start it one was of those songs you want to hear again and again. It just felt really right. I went into the studio and did my own thing with it, trying to give it a little more attitude than the demo. In 10 days, I never even saw Sweden. We were so busy."|source=—Spears talking to Chuck Taylor of ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''.{{cite journal |author= |year=1998 |title=Jive's Britney Spears Sets Top 40 Abuzz With Rhythm-Leaning 'Baby One More Time' |journal=Billboard |volume=110 |issue=43 |page=104 |publisher=Prometheus Global Media |issn=0006-2510 |url=http://books.google.com/?id=JQoEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA80&dq=%22...baby+one+more+time%22#v=onepage&q=%22...baby%20one%20more%20time%22&f=false |accessdate= September 21, 2011}} }} In June 1997, Spears was in talks with manager [[Lou Pearlman]] to join female pop group Innosense. Lynne asked family friend and entertainment lawyer Larry Rudolph for his opinion and submitted a tape of Spears singing over a Whitney Houston karaoke song along with some pictures. Rudolph decided to pitch her to record labels, which required a professional [[demo (music)|demo]]. He sent Spears an unused song from Toni Braxton; she rehearsed for a week and recorded in a studio with a [[Audio engineering|sound engineer]]. Spears traveled to New York with the demo and met executives from four labels, returning to Kentwood the same day. Three rejected her, arguing audiences wanted pop bands such as the [[Backstreet Boys]] and the [[Spice Girls]], and "there wasn't going to be another Madonna, another [[Debbie Gibson]] or another [[Tiffany (American singer)|Tiffany]]." Two weeks later, executives from Jive Records returned calls to Rudolph.{{harvnb|Hughes|2005|p=145}} Senior vice president of [[Artists and repertoire|A&R]] Jeff Fenster stated, "It's very rare to hear someone that age who can deliver emotional content and commercial appeal. [...] For any artist, the motivation—the 'eye of the tiger'— is extremely important. And Britney had that."{{cite journal|url=|title=Cover Story: Britney Spears: Britney Spears : Rolling Stone|date=April 15, 1999|work=Rolling Stone|publisher=[[Jann Wenner]]|last=Daly|first=Steven|issn=0035-791X}} They appointed her to work with producer Eric Foster White for a month, who reportedly shaped her voice from "lower and less poppy" delivery to "distinctively, unmistakably Britney."{{harvnb|Hughes|2005|p=147}} Spears recorded ten songs with White, including "Autumn Goodbye", "E-Mail My Heart", "From the Bottom of My Broken Heart", "I'm So Curious", "I Will Still Love You", "Soda Pop", and "Thinkin' About You".''...Baby One More Time'' liner notes. [[Jive Records]] (1999) The singer also recorded a cover of [[Sonny & Cher]]'s 1967 single "[[The Beat Goes On]]". White was responsible for the vocal recording and song production, while additional production was done by English electronic music group [[All Seeing I]]. After hearing the material, president [[Clive Calder]] ordered a full album. Spears flew to [[Cheiron Studios]] in [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]], where half of the album was recorded from March to April 1998, with producers Max Martin, Denniz Pop and Rami Yacoub, among others.{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/britneyspears/articles/story/5938512/cover_story_britney_spears|title=Cover Story: Britney Spears|date=April 15, 1999|publisher=''[[Rolling Stone]]''. [[Jann Wenner|Wenner Media]]|accessdate=March 5, 2011|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080505011004/http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/britneyspears/articles/story/5938512/cover_story_britney_spears|archivedate=May 5, 2008}} Martin showed Spears and her management a track titled "Hit Me Baby One More Time", which was originally written for American [[R&B]] group [[TLC (band)|TLC]]; however, they rejected it. Spears later claimed that she felt excited when she heard it and knew it was going to be a hit.{{Cite episode |title=E! Entertainment Special: Britney Spears |url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0427200/ |accessdate= |credits=Ray W. Keziah |network=[[E!]] |station= |city= |airdate=2004-03-14 |minutes=60 |language=English}} "We at Jive said, 'This is a fuckin' smash'," revealed the label's A&R executive, Steven Lunt;{{harvnb|Knopper|2009|p=93}} however, other executives were concerned that the line "Hit Me" would condone [[domestic violence]], and later revised it to "...Baby One More Time". The singer revealed that she "didn't do well at all the first day in the studio [recording the song], I was just too nervous. So I went out that night and had some fun. The next day I was completely relaxed and nailed it. You gotta be relaxed singing '... Baby One More Time'."{{cite journal|url=|title=The 500 Greatest Songs Since You Were Born - Blender|work=[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]]|publisher=Alpha Media Group|last=Staff|first=Blender|issn=1534-0554}} By June 1998, the album was done,{{harvnb|Parish|2002|p=243}} and Spears embarked on a promotional tour sponsored by [[L'Oreal]].{{harvnb|Blandford|2002|p=28}} ''...Baby One More Time'' was released as Spears' debut album on January 12, 1999.{{harvnb|Blandford|2002|p=30}} ==Composition== Spears had originally envisioned "[[Sheryl Crow]] music, but younger more adult contemporary", but felt all right with her label's producers, since "It made more sense to go pop, because I can dance to it—it's more me." The album opens with the first single "[[...Baby One More Time]]", a [[teen pop]] and [[dance-pop]] song that begins with a three-note [[motif (music)|motif]] in the bass range of the [[piano]]. The opening was compared to many other songs, such as "[[We Will Rock You]]" (1977), "[[Start Me Up]]" (1981) and the theme song of the film ''[[Jaws (film)|Jaws]]'' due to the fact the track "makes its presence known in exactly one second".{{cite web|url=http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtdVPE.asp?ppn=MN0027207|title=Britney Spears Baby One More Time - Sheet Music|work=Music Notes|publisher=[[Alfred Music Publishing]]|accessdate=November 21, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://allmusic.com/album/baby-one-more-time-us-cd-single-r377377|title=...Baby One More Time (US CD Single) - Britney Spears|publisher=[[Allmusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]]|accessdate=September 26, 2011|date=April 20, 1999}} According to magazine ''[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]]'', "...Baby One More Time" is composed by "[[wah-wah (music)|wah-wah]] guitar lines and [[electrocardiography|EKG]]-machine bass-slaps". Claudia Mitchell and Jacqueline Reid-Walsh, authors of ''Girl Culture: Studying girl culture : a readers' guide'' (2008), observed that the lyrics of the song "gesture toward [Spears] longing for the return of an ex-boyfriend."{{harvnb|Mitchell|Reid-Walsh|2008|p=547}} The next song and third single, "[[(You Drive Me) Crazy]]" runs through a [[down-tempo|moderately slow]] [[dance music|dance]] [[beat (music)|beat]],{{cite web|url=http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtdVPE.asp?ppn=MN0028943|title=Britney Spears (You Drive Me) Crazy - Sheet Music|work=Music Notes|publisher=[[Alfred Music Publishing]]|accessdate=November 21, 2009}} and has a [[R&B|rhythm and blues]] [[melody]] mixed with edgy synthesized instrumentals.{{harvnb|Bennett|Petterson|2004|p=92}} The third track and second single "[[Sometimes (Britney Spears song)|Sometimes]]" is a [[Ballad (music)|ballad]],{{cite web|url=http://buzzworthy.mtv.com/2010/09/15/snooki-britney-spears/|title=Snooki Lip-Synchs To Britney Spears' 'Sometimes'|last=Ryan|first=Chris|date=September 15, 2010|publisher=MTV. [[MTV Networks]]|accessdate=March 6, 2011}} that Spears begins with "You tell me you're in love with me/That you can't take your pretty eyes away from me/It's not that I don't wanna stay/But every time you come too close I move away".{{cite web|url=http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtd.asp?ppn=MN0026598|title=Britney Spears – Sometimes Sheet Music (Digital Download)|work=Music Notes|publisher=[[Alfred Music Publishing]]|accessdate=November 21, 2009}} [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] of [[Allmusic]] noted the song has "a catchy hook and endearing melody, with a reminiscent [[euro-dance]] rhythm."{{cite web|url=http://allmusic.com/album/baby-one-more-time-r384763/review|title=Britney Spears ...Baby One More Time – Album Review|date=January 12, 1999|last=Elerwine|first=Stephen Thomas|publisher=[[Allmusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]]|accessdate=April 2, 2011}} After "Sometimes" is ''...Baby One More Time's'' fourth track, "Soda Pop", a song that draws influences from [[bubblegum pop]] and [[dancehall]],{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.com/dp/b000023y30/|title=Amazon.com: Baby One More Time (Import): Britney Spears: Music|date=March 15, 1999|accessdate=September 28, 2011|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]}} and features background vocals from co-writer Mikey Bassie. Spears' vocals on the fifth track and fourth single, "[[Born to Make You Happy]]", span more than an [[octave]].{{cite web|url=http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtd.asp?ppn=MN0028935|title=Britney Spears Born to Make You Happy – Digital Sheet Music|work=Music Notes|publisher=[[Universal Music Publishing Group]]|accessdate=December 23, 2010}} Its lyrics allude to a relationship that a woman desires to repair, not quite understanding what went wrong, as she comes to realize that "I don't know how to live without your love/I was born to make you happy".{{cite web|url=http://newsroom.mtv.com/2010/03/03/britney-spears-baby-one-more-time/|title=Britney Spears Goes Back To Her Schoolgirl Days For The First Installment Of 'Popology'|date=March 3, 2010|last=Anderson|first=Kyle|publisher=MTV. [[MTV Networks]]|accessdate=March 5, 2011}} The sixth track and final single, "[[From the Bottom of My Broken Heart]]", is a sentimental slow-tempo [[teen pop]] ballad.{{cite web|url=http://new.music.yahoo.com/britney-spears/tracks/from-the-bottom-of-my-broken-heart--1486509|title=From the Bottom of My Broken Heart by Britney Spears|publisher=Yahoo! Music|accessdate=March 4, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://buzzworthy.mtv.com/2009/09/28/vintage-video-britney-spears-flashback/|title=Vintage Video: Britney Spears Flashback|author=Ryan, Chris|date=September 28, 2009|publisher=MTV. [[MTV Networks]]|accessdate=December 25, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtdVPE.asp?ppn=MN0028938|title=Britney Spears From The Bottom Of My Broken Heart – Digital Sheet Music|work=Music Notes|publisher=[[Universal Music Publishing Group]]|accessdate=November 15, 2010}} "I Will Be There" features a guitar riff similar to [[Natalie Imbruglia]]'s "[[Torn (Natalie Imbruglia song)|Torn]]" (1997), with a "rousing chorus about standing by your man (or a best friend or a house pet)", as noted by Kyle Anderson of [[MTV]]. The eleventh track, "E-Mail My Heart", is a sensitive piano ballad where Spears sings, "E-mail me back/ And say our love will stay alive". The cover of [[Sonny & Cher]]'s 1967 single "[[The Beat Goes On]]" is influenced by [[bossa nova]] and [[trip hop]],{{cite web|url=http://travel.canoe.ca/AllPop-SpearsBritney/cd_baby2.html|title=Britney Spears' debut rather lackluster|last=Stevenson|first=Jane|date=January 17, 1999|accessdate=September 3, 2011|work=[[Toronto Sun]]|publisher=Mike Power}} and features a similar sound to [[spy film|spy movies]] themes. ==Critical reception== {{Album ratings |rev1=[[Allmusic]] |rev1Score={{rating|4|5}} |rev2=[[Amazon.com]] |rev2Score=(mixed) |rev3=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |rev3Score=(favorable) |rev4=[[Robert Christgau]] |rev4Score={{rating-Christgau|hm1}}{{cite web|url=http://www.robertchristgau.com/get_artist.php?id=195&name=Britney+Spears|first=Robert|last=Christgau|title=Britney Spears' reviews|date=January 12, 1999|accessdate=October 4, 2011|publisher=Robert Christgau}} |rev5=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' |rev5Score=(B-) |rev6=[[MTV]] |rev6Score=(mixed) |rev7=''[[Rolling Stone]]'' |rev7Score={{rating|2|5}}{{cite web|first=Barry |last=Walters|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/baby-one-more-time-20030113|title=...Baby One More Time Music Review|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|publisher=[[Jann Wenner|Wenner Media]]|date=January 13, 2003|accessdate=March 2, 2011}} |rev8=[[Sputnikmusic]] |rev8Score=(2/5) |rev9=''[[The Hamilton Spectator]]'' |rev9Score={{rating|2.5|5}} }} ''...Baby One More Time'' received mixed reviews from critics. Stephen Thomas Erlewine of Allmusic gave the album four out of five stars,{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r384763|pure_url=yes}} |title=...Baby One More Time |publisher=[[Allmusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] |first=Stephen Thomas|last=Erlewine |date=January 12, 1999 |accessdate=November 13, 2008}} and commented that, by the time Spears launched her career, "everything old was new again", comparing the album to ''[[Hangin' Tough]]'' (1988) by [[New Kids on the Block]]. Erlewine further complimented the quality of the singles while praising Max Martin, "who is also the mastermind behind Spears' debut." ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'''s Beth Johnson noted the singer "sounds remarkably like the [[Backstreet Boys]]' kid sister", saying, however, that this was "not surprising, since BSB hit-meister Max Martin wrote the candy-pop-with-a-funky-edge smash debut."{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,286184,00.html |title=...Baby One More Time (1999) |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |publisher=[[Time Warner]] |first=Beth |last=Johnson |date=December 18, 1998 |accessdate=November 13, 2008}} [[Robert Christgau]] commented Spears portrayed a "Madonna next door" in the album with songs like "...Baby One More Time" and "Soda Pop", while Craig McDennis of ''[[The Hamilton Spectator]]'' said the album "offers a glib compendium of soul/pop cliches, served with a giddy, uptempo verve that recalls [[Debbie Gibson]] on a chocolate high."{{cite news|url=http://travel.canoe.ca/AllPop-SpearsBritney/cd_baby1.html|title=Bopper babe's CD glib collection of cliches|last=McDennis|first=Craig|date=January 12, 1999|accessdate=September 3, 2011|work=[[The Hamilton Spectator]]|publisher=Dana Robbins}} [[Amazon.com]]'s Rickey Wright gave ''...Baby One More Time'' a mixed review, saying that "a few of the disc's cuts are pleasantly catchy", noting, however, "neither does the 17-year-old Spears's debut album contain anything else that remotely approaches that instant hit single ['...Baby One More Time']." ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''{{'}}s Paul Verna considered the album "a top 40-ready workout filled with hook-laden songs from the same bag as the title cut".{{cite journal|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=1Q0EAAAAMBAJ|title=Albums|date=January 30, 1999|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|accessdate=October 8, 2011|last=Verna|first=Paul|issn=0006-2510}} Kyle Anderson of [[MTV]] said he "was surprised in more ways than one "with his first listening of ''...Baby One More Time'', commenting he "expected there to be a lot of filler (there sort of is), though I didn't expect it to be as odd (at least sonically) as it ended up being. There has never been any mystery to why Spears became such a superstar, but these songs probably would have been huge even if Britney wore burlap sacks in all of her videos." Barry Walters of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' gave the album two stars out of five, and compared the album's sound to early hits of Debbie Gibson, Mariah Carey, and [[Samantha Fox]]. Walters also said that "while several Cherion-crafted kiddie-funk jams serve up beefy hooks, shameless schlock slowies, like 'E-Mail My Heart', are pure spam." A ''[[NME]]'' reviewer rated ''...Baby One More Time'' 1 out of 10, saying that "we seem to have reached crisis point: pubescent pop is now so rife that 17-year-old Britney 'lizard-lounge' Spears is already halfway through her lucrative showbiz career".{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/reviews/britney-spears/853|title=...Baby One More Time|date=March 6, 1999|accessdate=October 4, 2011|work=[[NME]]|publisher=[[IPC Media]]}} He also found the album premature, commenting, "hopefully, if she starts to live the wretched life that we all eventually do, her voice will show the scars, she'll stop looking so fucking smug, she'll find solace in drugs and we'll be all the more happier for it. Now grow up, girl. Quick!" Amanda Murray of [[Sputnikmusic]] felt that, "with the exception of the terrific title track, ''...Baby One More Time'' is a collection of either competent pop songs underwhelmingly executed or underwhelmingly written pop songs competently executed."{{cite web|url=http://www.sputnikmusic.com/review/5825/Britney-Spears-...Baby-One-More-Time/|title=Britney Spears - ...Baby One More Time (staff review)|author=Murray, Amanda|date=March 26, 2006|publisher=Sputnikmusic|accessdate=December 25, 2010}} ==Commercial performance== [[File:Britney Spears 2002 1.jpg|left|thumb|220px|Spears performing "[[(You Drive Me) Crazy]]" during the [[Dream Within a Dream Tour]], 2001.|alt=Image of a blond female performer. She is turning her back to the camera, near the end of the stage. She is wearing black pants and a black top with long sleeves, showing her midriff. In front of her, a female dancer is climbing into a pole. A crowd of people clapping, screaming and taking pictures stands can be seen in the audience.]] ''...Baby One More Time'' debuted at number one on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] selling 121,000 units,{{cite web| author=Craig Rosen | title=Britney Spears Debuts On Top; 'N Sync At No. 2 | date=January 20, 1999 |publisher=Yahoo! Music News | url=http://www.music.yahoo.ca/read/news/12040569|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5iXT45JI5|archivedate=July 25, 2009|deadurl=no|accessdate=July 23, 2009}} replacing [[DMX (rapper)|DMX]]'s ''[[Flesh of My Flesh, Blood of My Blood]]'' (1998). Spears broke several records by doing so. The singer became the first new female artist to have a number one single on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 and number one album on the ''Billboard'' 200 at the same time; the first new artist (male or female) to have a single go to the number one spot the same week that the album debuted at number one; and the first new female artist to have the first single and first album at number one the same week. Spears is also the youngest female in ''Billboard'' history to have a simultaneous number and album at number in the same week.{{cite web|url=http://www.music.yahoo.ca/read/news/12050537|title='99 REWIND: The Year Of Britney Spears|publisher=Yahoo! Music News|last=Rosen|first=Craig|date=December 30, 1999|accessdate=December 28, 2012}} After four weeks since its release, the album had sold more than 500,000 copies, according to [[Nielsen SoundScan]] sales data.{{cite web| first=Craig |last=Rosen | title=Britney Spears Back On Top | date=February 10, 1999 |publisher=Yahoo! Music News | url=http://www.music.yahoo.ca/read/news/12063283|accessdate=May 10, 2011}} After dropping to the top five, the album went back to number one in its fourth week, with a total of 804,200 units sold.{{cite web| first=Craig |last=Rosen | title=Britney Still On Top, Offspring Up To No. 2, Cher In Top 10 | date=February 17, 1999 |publisher=Yahoo! Music News | url=http://www.music.yahoo.ca/read/news/12058414|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5iXT4UvTR|archivedate=July 5, 2009|deadurl=no|accessdate=July 23, 2009}} On its fifth week it reached its highest sales week with 229,000 copies sold. ''...Baby One More Time'' spent a total of six non-consecutive weeks at number one, and sold more than 1,8 million copies in its first two months of release in the country.{{cite web| author=Craig Rosen | title=Britney Spears 'One More Time' Again | date=March 31, 1999 |publisher=Yahoo! Music News | url=http://www.music.yahoo.ca/read/news/12039233|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5iXT6D4Sq|archivedate=July 5, 2009|deadurl=no|accessdate=July 23, 2009}} In its 47th week on the ''Billboard'' 200, the album held strong at number three, and with sales of over of 10 million copies in the United States alone.{{cite web| first=Craig |last=Rosen | title=Britney Spears Backstage At The 'Billboard Awards' | date=December 10, 1999 |publisher=Yahoo! Music News | url=http://www.music.yahoo.ca/read/news/12046646|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5iXT3MQGY|archivedate=July 25, 2009|deadurl=no|accessdate=July 23, 2009}} The album was later certified Diamond by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]], making Spears the youngest artist to receive that award, breaking [[Alanis Morissette]]'s record, who was 21 when she released ''[[Jagged Little Pill]]'' (1995).{{cite web|url=http://www.riaa.com/newsitem.php?content_selector=newsandviews&news_month_filter=12&news_year_filter=1999&id=C29FB2E9-763C-3D37-9153-6E3E41FA6DD1&searchterms=britney%20diamond&terminclude=&termexact=|title=Recording Industry Announces 1999 Gold and Platinum Awards|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]]|date=December 21, 1999|accessdate=October 5, 2011}} The album was the fourteenth album since 1991 to sell over 10 million copies in the United States,{{cite web|last=Caulfield|first=Keith|title=Usher's 'Confessions' Album Hits 10 Million in U.S. Sales|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/482065/ushers-confessions-album-hits-10-million-in-us-sales|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=July 5, 2012}} and Spears became the best-selling female artist of 1999. ''...Baby One More Time'' spent a total of fifty-one weeks in the top ten of the ''Billboard'' 200.{{cite web| first=Wendy |last=Hermanson | title=Britney Spears Readies A Funky New Album | date=January 7, 2000 |publisher=Yahoo! Music News | url=http://ca.music.yahoo.com/read/news/12045573|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5iXT6jJ9B|archivedate=July 5, 2009|deadurl=no|accessdate=July 23, 2009}} The album spent a total of 103 weeks on the chart.{{cite web|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=britney spears|chart=all}} |title=...Baby One More Time Chart History |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |year=1999 |accessdate=October 5, 2011}} ''...Baby One More Time'' landed at number three on [[BMG]] Music Club all-time best-sellers list, selling 1.6 million units, behind [[Shania Twain]]'s ''[[Come on Over (Shania Twain album)|Come on Over]]'' (1997).{{cite web| first=Barry |last=David | title=Shania, Backstreet, Britney, Eminem and Janet Top All-Time Sellers | publisher=Music Industry News Network | date=February 18, 2003 | url=http://www.mi2n.com/press.php3?press_nb=47877 | accessdate=May 17, 2009|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5jW8qIpnZ|archivedate=September 3, 2009|deadurl=no}} The album debuted at number one on the [[Canadian Albums Chart]], totaling nine non-consecutive weeks at the top.{{cite web| title=Canadian Albums Chart |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] | url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/1999-01-30/canadian-albums | date=January 30, 1999 | accessdate=May 8, 2011}}{{cite web| title=Canadian Albums Chart |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] | url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/1999-03-27/canadian-albums | date=March 27, 1999 | accessdate=May 8, 2011}}{{cite web| title=Canadian Albums Chart |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] | url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/1999-04-17/canadian-albums | date=April 17, 1999 | accessdate=May 8, 2011}} On December 12, 1999, the [[Canadian Recording Industry Association]] certified it Diamond, for sales over 1 million units.{{Certification Cite Ref|region = Canada|title = Baby One More Time|artist = Britney Spears|type = album}} ''...Baby One More Time'' spent two weeks at number two on the [[European Top 100 Albums]], and sold over four million copies within the continent, being certified quadruple platinum by the [[International Federation of the Phonographic Industry]].{{Certification Cite Ref|region = Europe|title = Baby One More Time|artist = Britney Spears|type = album|certyear = 2000}} The album reached number two in the [[UK Albums Chart|United Kingdom]], number four in [[Syndicat National de l'Édition Phonographique|France]] and was certified triple Platinum by the [[British Phonographic Industry]],{{Certification Cite Ref|region = United Kingdom|title = Baby One More Time|artist = Britney Spears|type = album}} double Platinum by the [[Syndicat National de l'Édition Phonographique]],{{Certification Cite Ref|region = France|title = Baby One More Time|artist = Britney Spears|type = album|award = Platinum|number = 2|certyear = 2001}} triple Gold in Germany by the [[International Federation of the Phonographic Industry]],{{Certification Cite Ref|region = Germany|title = Baby One More Time|artist = Britney Spears|type = album}} and ten-times Platinum (Diamond) by the [[Polish Society of the Phonographic Industry]].{{Certification Cite Ref|region = Poland|title = Baby One More Time|artist = BritneySpears|type = album|award = Platinum|number = 1|certyear = 1999}} ''...Baby One More Time'' debuted at number nine in May 1999 on the [[ARIA Charts|Australian Albums Chart]], reaching at number two nine weeks later, placing behind the [[Dawson's Creek#Music|''Dawson's Creek'' soundtrack]]. The album became the seventh highest-selling of 1999 in the country, and was certified four-times Platinum by the [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] the following year after shipping 280,000 copies to retailers.{{cite web| url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-end-of-year-charts-top-100-albums-1999.htm | title=Australian Annual Chart | author=Australian Recording Industry Association | year=1999 | accessdate=July 19, 2009 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5iPwC4Tdx|archivedate=July 20, 2009|deadurl=no}}{{Certification Cite Ref|region = Australia|title = Baby One More Time|artist = Britney Spears|type = album|certyear = 2000}} The track debuted at number three in the [[Recording Industry Association of New Zealand|New Zealand]], placing behind Shania Twain's ''Come on Over'' and [[The Corrs]]'.{{cite web| url=http://www.rianz.org.nz/rianz/chart.asp | title=New Zealand Music Charts| publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of New Zealand]] | date=May 30, 1999 | accessdate=July 13, 2009| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5PkfqxTDF | archivedate =June 20, 2007| deadurl=no}} Album Chart#1161 The album was later certified triple Platinum in the country by the [[Recording Industry Association of New Zealand]].{{Certification Cite Ref|region = New Zealand|title = Baby One More Time|artist = Britney Spears|type = album|id = 1212}} ==Singles== "[[...Baby One More Time]]" was released as Spears' debut single on October 23, 1998.{{harvnb|Gaines|1999|p=26}} The song received generally favorable critical reviews, mostly praising its composition. "...Baby One More Time" attained worldwide success, reaching number one in every European country where it charted.{{cite web| url=http://australian-charts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Britney+Spears&titel=...Baby+One+More+Time&cat=s | title=Britney Spears – ...Baby One More Time - Charts Around the World | publisher=[[ARIA Charts|ARIA Top 50 Singles]]. Hung Medien | date=February 28, 1999 | accessdate=October 23, 2010}} It received numerous certifications around the world, and is one of the [[List of best-selling singles worldwide|best-selling singles of all time]], at over ten million copies.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/6376213.stm | work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=BBC | title=How Disney's TV gang has grown up | date=February 20, 2007|accessdate=May 2, 2011}} An accompanying music video, directed by [[Nigel Dick]], portrays Spears as a student from a [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] high school, who starts to [[daydream]] that she is singing and dancing around the school, while watching her love interest from afar.{{cite web |publisher=MTV. [[MTV Networks]] | title=Britney Spears Shoots For Fun With Video Debut | date=December 18, 1998 | url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1434423/19981218/spears_britney.jhtml | accessdate=July 30, 2008}} In 2010, the music video for "...Baby One More Time" was voted the third-most influential video in the history of [[pop music]].{{cite web|url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/2010/05/03/13804931-wenn-story.html|title='Thriller' tops best video poll |publisher=[[Jam!]]. [[Sun Media]]|date=May 3, 2010|accessdate=May 2, 2011}} "[[Sometimes (Britney Spears song)|Sometimes]]" was released as the second single on April 30, 1999.{{cite web|url=http://www.britney.com/us/making-britstory|title=Making BRITstory|author=BRITannica|accessdate=October 3, 2011|publisher=Britney.com. [[Sony Music Entertainment]]}} "Sometimes" achieved commercial success worldwide, reaching number one in [[Ultratop 50|Belgium (Flanders)]], [[Mega Single Top 100|Netherlands]] and [[Recording Industry Association of New Zealand|New Zealand]],{{cite web | url=http://hitparade.ch/showitem.asp?interpret=Britney+Spears&titel=Sometimes&cat=s | title=Britney Spears – Sometimes Chart History | publisher= Hung Medien| date= | accessdate=March 2, 2011}} while peaking inside the top five in four countries. In the United States, "Sometimes" missed the top ten, peaking at number twenty-one on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].{{cite web|url=http://allmusic.com/artist/britney-spears-p320976/charts-awards/billboard-singles|title=Britney Spears Billboard Charts|accessdate=September 28, 2011|publisher=[[Allmusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]]}} The music video for the song was directed by Nigel Dick.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1431411/will-smith-britney-spears-jennifer-lopez-star-wars-among-videos-set-debut.jhtml|title=Will Smith, Britney Spears, Jennifer Lopez, "Star Wars" Among Videos Set To Debut|date=April 29, 1999|publisher=MTV. [[MTV Networks]]|accessdate=March 6, 2011}} During rehearsals, on February 11, 1999, Spears injured her left knee and needed surgery.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1434419/britney-spears-knee-injury-delays-video-shoot-tonight-show-appearance.jhtml|title=Britney Spears' Knee Injury Delays Video Shoot, "Tonight Show" Appearance|date=February 18, 1999|publisher=MTV. [[MTV Networks]]|accessdate=2013-12-10}} After recuperating in [[Kentwood, Louisiana]], the music video was shot on April 9–10, 1999 at Paradise Cove in [[Malibu, California]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/photos/mtv-buzzworthy-blog-best-of-britney/1649473/5296696/photo.jhtml|title=Britney shooting 'Sometimes' video in April 1999|publisher=MTV. [[MTV Networks]]|date=October 6, 2010|accessdate=February 7, 2011}} It was released on May 6, 1999 on [[MTV]]'s ''[[Total Request Live]]''. In May 1999, Max Martin and Spears went to the Battery Studios in [[New York City, New York]] to re-record the vocals of "[[(You Drive Me) Crazy]]",{{cite album-notes|format=Liner notes |title=(You Drive Me) Crazy [The Stop! Remix]|year=1999|artist=Britney Spears|publisher=Jive Records|publisherid=0550672}} due to the fact that a remixed version called "The Stop! Remix" was going to be included on the original motion picture soundtrack of the film ''[[Drive Me Crazy]]'' (1999).{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00001O2UF|title=Amazon.com: Drive Me Crazy (1999 Film): Various Artists - Soundtracks: Music|date=September 28, 1999|accessdate=September 28, 2011|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]}} "The Stop! Remix" of the song was released as the third single on August 23, 1999. The music video was directed by Nigel Dick, and featured actors [[Melissa Joan Hart]] and [[Adrian Grenier]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1626386/director-recalls-making-britney-spears-drive-me-crazy-video.jhtml|title=Britney Spears Wanted '(You Drive Me) Crazy' Video To Take Her 'To The Next Level' |last=Vena |first=Jocelyn |date=November 16, 2009 |accessdate=April 24, 2011 |publisher=[[MTV]]. [[MTV Networks]]}} "[[Born to Make You Happy]]" was released on December 6, 1999 as the fourth single,{{cite web|url=http://www.swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Britney+Spears&titel=Born+to+Make+You+Happy&cat=s|title=Swedishcharts.com – Britney Spears – Born to Make You Happy|publisher=[[Ultratop]] & Hung Medien / hitparade.ch|accessdate=March 5, 2011}} and received mixed reviews from music critics.{{cite web|url=http://www.musicomh.com/albums/britney-spears.htm|last=Petch-Jex|first=Andy|title=Britney Spears - Greatest Hits: My Prerogative - Album Review|date=November 8, 2004|publisher=musicOMH|accessdate=March 5, 2011}} The song achieved commercial success, peaking inside the top-five in eleven countries. The music video for it was directed by [[Billie Woodruff]] and produced by Geneva Films,{{cite video |people=Spears, Britney |date=November 9, 2004 |title=Greatest Hits: My Prerogative |url=http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00064AM62 |format=DVD |language=English |publisher=Zomba/Jive Label Group |archiveurl=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0480109/ |archivedate=2004 |accessdate=February 4, 2011 |asin=B00064AM62 }} choreographed by [[Wade Robson]].{{cite web|url=http://www.msaagency.com/waderobson/|title=Wade Robson, Producer/Director/Choreographer|publisher=McDonald / Selznick Associates|accessdate=May 7, 2011}} "[[From the Bottom of My Broken Heart]]" was released on December 15, 1999 as the final single.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1431167/britney-spears-announce-tour-with-lfo.jhtml|title=Britney Spears To Announce Tour With LFO|author=Johnson, Tine|date=December 8, 1999|publisher=MTV. [[MTV Networks]]|accessdate=February 4, 2011}} The song also received mixed reviews, finding the song a classic hit and competent single, despite considering it as an unremarkable song that refers only to kissing. "From the Bottom of My Broken Heart" achieved moderate success, peaking at number thirty-seven in Australia, and twenty-three in New Zealand.{{cite web|url=http://www.australian-charts.com/search.asp?search=britney+spears&cat=s|title=Australian-charts.com – Britney Spears – From the Bottom of My Broken Heart|publisher=[[ARIA charts|ARIA Top 50 Singles]]. Hung Medien|accessdate=November 15, 2010}} Through imports, the song reached one hundred seventy-four in the United Kingdom.{{cite web|url=http://www.zobbel.de/|title=UK Chart History - Searchable Database|date=March 11, 2000|work=The Official Charts Company|publisher=Zobbel|accessdate=April 24, 2011}} In the United States, "From the Bottom of My Broken Heart" reached number fourteen on ''Billboard'' Hot 100, and seventeen on Pop Songs,{{cite journal |author= |year=2000 |title=Hot 100 Spotlight |journal=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |volume=112 |issue=9 |page=108 |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |issn=0006-2510 |doi= |pmid= |pmc= |url=http://books.google.com/?id=ag4EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA97&dq=%22from+the+bottom+of+my+broken+heart%22#v=onepage&q=%22from%20the%20bottom%20of%20my%20broken%20heart%22&f=false |accessdate= December 25, 2010}} and was later certified Platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA) on March 28, 2000, for selling over 1,000,000 physical units of the single.{{cite web|url=http://riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?resultpage=1&table=SEARCH_RESULTS&action=&title=From%20The%20Bottom%20of%20My%20Broken%20Heart&artist=Britney%20Spears&format=&debutLP=&category=&sex=&releaseDate=&requestNo=&type=&level=&label=&company=&certificationDate=&awardDescription=&catalogNo=&aSex=&rec_id=&charField=&gold=&platinum=&multiPlat=&level2=&certDate=&album=&id=&after=&before=&startMonth=1&endMonth=1&startYear=1958&endYear=2009&sort=Artist&perPage=25|title=RIAA certification searchable database - "Britney Spears"|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]]|date=March 28, 2000|accessdate=November 15, 2010}} The music video, directed by [[Gregory Dark]], was released on December 17, 1999. It was highly criticized due to the fact that Dark had previously directed porn films.{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/2000-02-10/music/the-devil-in-miss-spears/|title=The Devil in Miss Spears|last=Bemis|first=Alec Hanley|date=February 10, 2000|work=[[LA Weekly]]|publisher=Beth Sestanovich|accessdate=March 1, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,84970,00.html|title=X Marks the Shot|last=Seymour|first=Craig|date=February 4, 2000|publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''. [[Time Inc.|Time Inc]]|accessdate=March 1, 2011}} ==Promotion== [[File:Britney Spears Live Paris 6.jpg|thumb|right|Spears performing "[[...Baby One More Time]]" during the [[The Circus Starring Britney Spears]], 2009.|alt=A blond female performer. She is standing on a moving jungle gym, wearing black and white clothes.]] Promotion began in 1998, when Spears did a small tour in malls and food courts that were located mostly in larger cities around the United States. Each show lasted around 30 minutes, and Spears had two female dancers with her on the stage. The promo tour is also known as the L'Oreal Mall Tour, after its sponsor. The singer made several promotional appearances including talk shows and live performances around the world. On December 1998, Spears' first showed up on MTV's and the Box's most-requested video charts.{{cite web| first=Wendy |last=Hermanson | title=Britney Spears: New Teen Queen? | date=December 22, 1998 |publisher=Yahoo! Music News | url=http://www.music.yahoo.ca/read/news/12050778|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5iXSx3oMA|archivedate=July 25, 2009|deadurl=no|accessdate=July 23, 2009}} She also appeared on the ''[[Ricki Lake (TV series)|Ricki Lake Show]]'', the ''Howie Mandel Show'', and was the presenter of the 1999 [[American Music Awards of 1999|American Music Awards]], prior to the release of the album. The singer also appeared on MTV's ''Spring Break'' and on the 100th episode of [[Nickelodeon]]'s ''[[All That]]''. However, after hurting her knee, she had rescheduled appearances several shows such as ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'' and ''[[Live with Regis and Kelly|Live With Regis And Kathie Lee]]''.{{cite web| first=Craig |last=Rosen | title=Britney Spears Sidelined With Bum Knee | date=March 4, 1999 |publisher=Yahoo! Music News | url=http://www.music.yahoo.ca/read/news/12049598|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5iXSzFdBa|archivedate=July 25, 2009|deadurl=no|accessdate=July 23, 2009}} After recovering, Spears embarked on another promotional schedule. The singer appeared on Nickelodeon's 12th Annual Kids Choice Awards on May 1, MTV's ''FANatic'' on May 12, ''Live With Regis & Kathie Lee'' on May 3, and ''[[The Rosie O'Donnell Show]]'' on May 25.{{cite web| first=Craig |last=Rosen | title=Britney Spears Ready To Hit The Road | date=April 9, 1999 |publisher=Yahoo! Music News | url=http://www.music.yahoo.ca/read/news/12032891|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5iXT096Nq|archivedate=July 25, 2009|deadurl=no|accessdate=July 23, 2009}} Outside the United States, Spears visited German talk show ''[[Wetten, dass..?]]'' and ''[[Top of the Pops]]'' on June 25, 1999. She also went to the United Kingdom, making appearances on programmes such as ''[[This Morning (TV series)|This Morning]]'', ''[[CD:UK]]'' and ''[[National Lottery (United Kingdom)|National Lottery]]''. She visited a music variety show called ''[[Hey! Hey! Hey! Music Champ]]'' in Japan, and performed at the Festival Bar in Italy. Spears was also featured on an episode of [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] television sitcom, ''[[Sabrina, The Teenage Witch]]'', where she played herself.{{cite web| first=Craig |last=Rosen | title=Britney Spears: In Drag And On TV | date=August 4, 1999 |publisher=Yahoo! Music News | url=http://www.music.yahoo.ca/read/news/12045032|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5iXT18ZsF|archivedate=July 25, 2009|deadurl=no|accessdate=July 23, 2009}} Spears was returning a favor to actress [[Melissa Joan Hart]], who played a cameo role in Spears' video for "(You Drive Me) Crazy," according to ''People'' magazine. The episode aired on September 24, 1999. The same month, Spears performed on ''[[The Rosie O'Donnell Show]]'' on September 27, and visited [[Carson Daly]] on MTV's ''[[Total Request Live]]'' the following day.{{cite web| first=Craig |last=Rosen | title=Britney Spears Is All Over TV | date=September 24, 1999 |publisher=Yahoo! Music News | url=http://www.music.yahoo.ca/read/news/12041209|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5iXT1eIZl|archivedate=July 25, 2009|deadurl=no|accessdate=July 23, 2009}} She had a mini-[[Disney]] concert titled "Britney Spears & Joey McIntyre In Concert." Spears and [[Joey McIntyre]] performed live in the taped concert event.{{cite web| first=Craig |last=Rosen | title=Nirvana, Paul McCartney, And Britney Spears In Today's TV Tips | date=October 16, 1999 |publisher=Yahoo! Music News | url=http://www.music.yahoo.ca/read/news/12039519|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5iXT2Ecjj|archivedate=July 25, 2009|deadurl=no|accessdate=July 23, 2009}} Promotion for the album continued in early 2000, where Spears performed at the [[American Music Awards of 2000]], and also performed "From the Bottom of My Broken Heart" in a medley with "...Baby One More Time" at the [[2000 Grammy Awards]]. ===Touring=== {{Main|...Baby One More Time Tour|(You Drive Me) Crazy Tour}} On March 5, 1999, it was reported that Spears was planning her first headlining tour.{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1099891_0_274628_6,00.html|title=Bubble Gum Blows Up! |date=March 5, 1999|accessdate=December 31, 2009|last=Essex|first=Andrew|last2=Karger|first2=Dave|last3=Baldwin|first3=Kristen|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Warner]]}} She announced that the tour would start in July.{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1434415/19990323/spears_britney.jhtml|title=Britney Spears Back In Action, Plans Summer Tour|date=March 23, 1999|accessdate=December 31, 2009|last=Staff|first=MTV News|publisher=[[MTV]]. [[MTV Networks]]}} On May 12, [[Tommy Hilfiger]] was announced as the main tour sponsor. During the time of the announcement, Spears was being featured in the company's "AllStars" campaign.{{cite press release |title=Tommy Hilfiger Announces Sponsorship of Britney Spears Summer Concert Tour|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_1999_May_12/ai_54609972/ |publisher= Business Wire |date=May 12, 1999 |accessdate=July 17, 2010}} On December 17, during the premiere of the music video of "[[From the Bottom of My Broken Heart]]" on ''[[Total Request Live|TRL]]'', Spears called the show to announce March 2000 US tour dates. The extension, entitled Crazy 2K Tour, was considered a prelude to her [[Oops!... I Did It Again World Tour|future world tour]].{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1434396/19991217/spears_britney.jhtml|title=Britney Spears Phones "TRL" To Announce U.S. Tour Dates|date=December 17, 1999|accessdate=January 1, 2010|last=Basham|first=David|publisher=[[MTV]]. [[MTV Networks]]}}{{cite journal|url=|title=The Girl Can't Help It |date=May 25, 2000|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|publisher=[[Jann Wenner]]|last=Mundy|first=Chris|issn=0035-791X}} The leg's main sponsor was [[Got Milk?]]. Media director Peter Gardiner explained, "Britney is magic with teen-age girls, and that's an absolutely crucial target for milk". Spears shot an advertising campaign to be shown before her performances began.{{cite news|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-60047306/milk-producers-back-britney.html|title=Milk producers back Britney Spears tour|date=March 6, 2000|accessdate=January 16, 2010|last=Thompson|first=Stephanie|work=[[Advertising Age]]|publisher=[[Crain Communications Inc.]]}} The secondary sponsor was [[Polaroid Corporation|Polaroid]] and the corporation released the [[I-Zone|Polaroid I-Zone]] as the tour's official camera. Spears used the I-Zone onstage to take pictures of the audience and further promote the product.{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-61398528.html|title=Polaroid and Britney Spears Will Drive You Crazy|date=April 7, 2000|accessdate=January 16, 2010|last=Reporter|first=PR Newswire|work=[[PR Newswire]]|publisher=}} The show was divided into segments, separated by interlude, ending with an encore. The setlist consisted of songs from her debut album and several [[cover version|covers]].{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/e/a/1999/07/30/WEEKEND10994.dtl&type=printable|title=The musical equivalent of cotton candy|date=July 30, 1999|accessdate=January 1, 2010|last=Ganahl|first=Jane|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]}} Some changes were made during the 2000 leg, with the covers replaced by songs from her second studio album, ''[[Oops!... I Did It Again]]''. The tour received positive critical appreciation.{{cite news|url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/S/Spears_Britney/1999/07/10/749831.html|title=Spears takes aim at fame|date=July 10, 1999|accessdate=January 1, 2010|last=Stevenson|first=Jane|work=[[Jam!]]|publisher=[[Quebecor Inc.]]}} During the tour, Spears was accused of lip synching, although she denied these claims. On April 20, 2000, the concert at [[Hilton Hawaiian Village]] in [[Honolulu, Hawaii]] was taped.{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Tc8yAAAAIBAJ&sjid=K6YEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5725,2814536&dq=britney+honolulu&hl=en|title=Spears special to include concert|date=April 15, 2000|accessdate=January 18, 2010|last=Reporter|first=The Tuscaloosa News|work=[[The Tuscaloosa News]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]}} It was slightly altered from its Crazy 2K incarnation and featured different costumes. On June 5, 2000, it was broadcast on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]].{{cite news|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/orlandosentinel/access/54798682.html?dids=54798682:54798682&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jun+05%2C+2000&author=Jim+Abbott+of+The+Sentinel+Staff+By+Jim+Abbott+of+The+Sentinel+Staff&pub=Orlando+Sentinel&desc=FOR+FOX%2C+IT%27S+GAMES+-+FOR+BRITNEY%2C+IT%27S+ALOHA&pqatl=google|title=FOR FOX, IT'S GAMES - FOR BRITNEY, IT'S ALOHA|date=June 5, 2000|accessdate=January 22, 2010|last=Abbott|first=Jim|work=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|publisher=[[Tribune Company]]}} The special was aired several times during the year. On November 21, 2000, Jive Records released the ''[[Live and More!]]'' [[DVD]], which included the Fox special.{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lugpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8c8EAAAAIBAJ&pg=4339,4328192&dq=britney+live+and+more&hl=en|title=Britney Spears 'Stronger'|date=November 10, 2000|accessdate=January 18, 2010|last=Reporter|first=Billboard|work=[[The Herald Journal]]|publisher=Pioneer Newspapers}} It was certified triple platinum by the RIAA for shipping 300,000 units.{{cite web|url=http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?resultpage=1&table=SEARCH_RESULTS&action=&title=live%20and%20more!&artist=Britney%20Spears&format=VIDEO%20LONGFORM&debutLP=&category=&sex=&releaseDate=&requestNo=&type=&level=&label=&company=&certificationDate=&awardDescription=&catalogNo=&aSex=&rec_id=&charField=&gold=&platinum=&multiPlat=&level2=&certDate=&album=&id=&after=&before=&startMonth=1&endMonth=1&startYear=1958&endYear=2009&sort=Artist&perPage=25|title=Britney Spears - Live and More!|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]] |date=November 15, 2001|accessdate=January 22, 2010}} ==Legacy== {{Quote box|width=30%|align=left|quote="With ''...Baby One More Time'', I didn't get to show my voice off. The songs were great, but they weren't very challenging." |source=—Spears reflects on ''...Baby One More Time'' in December 1999.{{Cite news | title='One more time' for Spears | newspaper=[[San Antonio Express-News]] | pages=4F | date=December 16, 1999 }}}} Spears was credited with leading the revival of [[teen pop]]. ''[[The Daily Yomiuri]]'' reported that "critics have hailed her as the most gifted teenage pop idol for many years, but Spears has set her sights a little higher-she is aiming for the level of superstardom that has been achieved by Madonna and Janet Jackson."{{Cite news|title=Teen pop idols stage comeback|newspaper=Yomiuri Shimbun|page=1|date=November 25, 1999|postscript=}} ''Rolling Stone'' wrote: "Britney Spears carries on the classic archetype of the rock & roll teen queen, the dungaree doll, the angel baby who just has to make a scene."{{Cite journal|url=|title=Oops!...I Did It Again|year=2000|work=Rolling Stone|publisher=[[Jann Wenner]]|issn=0035-791X}} Rami Yacoub who co-produced Spears's debut album with lyricist Max Martin commented, "I know from Denniz Pop and Max's previous productions, when we do songs, there's kind of a nasal thing. With N' Sync and the Backstreet Boys, we had to push for that mid-nasal voice. When Britney did that, she got this kind of raspy, sexy voice."{{cite book | last = Bronson | first = Fred| title = The Billboard book of number 1 hits | publisher=Billboard Books | year = 2003 | page = 377 | isbn = 978-0-8230-7677-2}} Chuck Taylor of ''Billboard'' observed, "Spears has become a consummate performer, with snappy dance moves, a clearly real-albeit young-and funkdified voice ... "(You Drive Me) Crazy", her third single ... demonstrates Spears' own development, proving that the 17-year-old is finding her own vocal personality after so many months of steadfast practice."{{Cite news |last=Taylor | first=Chuck | title=Britney Spears: (You Drive Me) Crazy | newspaper=Billboard |volume=111|issue=35| page=27 | date=August 28, 1999 |postscript=}} Stephen Thomas Erlewine of Allmusic referred to her music as a "blend of infectious, rap-inflected dance-pop and smooth balladry." Sputnikmusic writer Amanda Murray noted the album "offers a marker for Spears' progression as an artist, as a celebrity, and as a woman." Spears became an international [[pop icon|pop culture icon]] immediately after launching her recording career. ''Rolling Stone'' magazine wrote: "One of the most controversial and successful female vocalists of the 21st century," she "spearheaded the rise of post-millennial teen pop ... Spears early on cultivated a mixture of innocence and experience that broke the bank".{{cite web | title = Britney Spears: Biography: Rolling Stone |work=Rolling Stone |publisher=Jann Wenner | year = 2008 | url = http://www.rollingstone.com/music/artists/britney-spears/biography | accessdate = August 9, 2008}} She is listed by the ''[[Guinness World Records]]'' as having the "Best-selling album by a teenage solo artist".{{cite book | last = Folkard | first = Claire | title = Guinness World Records 2003 | publisher=Bantam Books | year = 2003 | page = 288 | isbn = 978-0-553-58636-7}} Melissa Ruggieri of the ''[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]'' reported, "She's also marked for being the best-selling teenage artist. Before she turned 20 in 2001, Spears sold more than 37 million albums worldwide".{{Cite news |last= Ruggieri | first=Melissa | title=Music Notes | newspaper=[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]| pages=D.13 | year=2002 | date=December 19, 2000 |postscript= }} Barbara Ellen of ''[[The Observer]]'' has reported: "Spears is famously one of the 'oldest' teenagers pop has ever produced, almost middle aged in terms of focus and determination. Many 19-year-olds haven't even started working by that age, whereas Britney, a former Mouseketeer, was that most unusual and volatile of American phenomena — a child with a full-time career. While other little girls were putting posters on their walls, Britney was wanting to be the poster on the wall. Whereas other children develop at their own pace, Britney was developing at a pace set by the ferociously competitive American entertainment industry".{{Cite news |last= Ellen | first=Barbara | title=Comment: Britney Spears: Growing up is hard to do: America's apple- pie cheerleader is feeling the pressure as she tries to break free from her clean teen image. So is it all proving too much for Britney Inc, as she pulls out of tonight's Smash Hits Poll Winners' party and takes to her bed: The Observer Profile: Britney Spears | newspaper=[[The Observer]] | page=27 | date=December 10, 2000|issn=00297712 |postscript= }} ''...Baby One More Time'' is Spears' most successful album to date, with worldwide sales over 30 million copies,{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/4723158/With-dreams-in-her-heart.html|title= With dreams in her heart|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=April 28, 2001}} and also the best-selling album by a teenage solo artist.Folkard, Claire (2003). ''Guinness World Records 2003''. Bantam Books. p. 288.
